body.p: The state of your ∏ development image is determined by a collection of changes (additions, deletions, edits, and evaluations) performed on the original image. All of these are tracked in the changes file associated with the image.
You can use the Change List and Change Set Browser to maintain the image and manage your development process.
change listopenTo open a new Change List, select Tools → Change List in the ∏ Launcher window.

p.xref: Open the Change List for me

body.p: systemview changeschange listview changes To load and display the changes that have occurred since the last snapshot was taken, select file in/out → recover last changes in the <Operate> menu of the list view at the top.
To load and display changes that are in the current Change Set, select file in/out → display system changes.
To view the contents of a file-in (or a group of file-ins) as a collection of changes, select file in/out → read file/directory... and supply the name of the file at the prompt.
To view the contents of a loaded parcel as a collection of changes, select Display Parcel... on the File menu, and choose the name of a parcel in the dialog box.
To display all changes saved, ignoring snapshot boundaries, select file in/out → read file/directory... from the <Operate> menu, and supply the name of the changes file (image.cha).
Changes from different sources can be loaded and viewed simultaneously in a single Change List.
When you select an entry, the code for the affected class or method appears in the lower text view as it existed after the change.
change listfilter listUse the switches in the upper right region of the Change List to filter the displayed list of changes.

Change List filter switches:
file
Display only entries that are recorded in the same disk file as the selected entry.
type
Display only entries of the same type as the selected entry (for example, all doIts, which represent executed expressions).
class
Display only entries that affect the same class as the selected entry.
protocol
Display only entries that affect a class or message in the same protocol as the selected entry.
selector
Display only entries that involve the same message selector as the selected entry.
same
Display only entries that have the same type as the selected entry and affect the same class or method. Although the entries in the change list appear identical, the underlying code may be different for each entry. Use this switch to examine the evolution of a change.

topic.title: Examine the evolution of a change

body.p: With the same filter turned on, you can examine the evolution of a class, method, or protocol. Typically, this filter is used to examine the evolution of a single class or a method, but it can be used to filter any type of change.

change listcull listTo pair down the list of displayed changes, mark those item(s) to be deleted by choosing remove selection or remove all from the <Operate> menu, and then forget. To un-mark item(s), choose either restore selection or restore all. Note that the forget operation does not permanently affect the system Change Set.

As a short-cut, you can also mark an item for removal by double-clicking on the list entry; items marked for removal are display is struck text. Double-clicking on the item a second time will restore it to the list.

recover changeschange listrecover changesTo display the changes that have occurred since the last snapshot was taken, select file in/out → recover last changes on the <Operate> menu of the list view in the top-left region of the window.

When recovering from a system failure, you must eliminate any changes that may have contributed to the crash.
To cull unnecessary entries such as doIts, edit the displayed list.
To delete all doIts, which are usually unnecessary for recovery purposes, select any doIt in the list view and select the type switch.
Choose remove all in the <Operate> menu to mark all the doIts for deletion, then select forget to clear them from the list.
Deselect the type switch to display the remaining changes.
When the displayed list contains only the desired changes, select replay all → from top in the <Operate> menu.

condense changeschanges filecondense In a large development effort spanning months or years of programming, the changes file can become very large. To condense it so that it contains only the most recent change for each method, select Changes → Condense Changes from the Launcher’s System menu. Changes involving anything other than a method — such as a class addition or redefinition — will also be purged from the file permanently. It’s a good idea to make a backup copy of the changes file before condensing it.

topic.title: Revert to a prior version of a change

body.p: revert to prior version change listrevert Use the same filter to see the evolution of the particular change you want to revert. To revert the code to a prior version, select the entry representing that version and then select replay selection in the <Operate> menu. You can also use the options under replay all, when you want to incorporate all of the listed changes. The menu item replay all → from here will revert every change listed from the current selection to the end of this list, while replay all → from top will revert every change in the list. Note that any change entries marked for removal will not be reverted. If an exception occurs during the replay, the selection is left at the item which caused it.

change setopenChange sets are listed in the Change Set Browser window. To open the browser, select Changes → Change Sets from the Launcher’s System menu. To browse the changes in a particular change set, select the change set then select Browse in the <Operate> menu. This will open a separate Change Set Browser.

p.xref: Open the Change Set Browser for me

body.p: To browse the changes in a specific change set, select the change set in the Change Set Browser, then select Browse in the ChangeSet or <Operate> menu.

Unlike the Change List, the change set browser does not show the evolution of changes. Instead, change sets are used to organize groups of changes. The Change Set Browser lists the affected parts of the system so you can use the File out as... command to store your work in a set of disk files.

change setcreate newTo create a new change set, open the Change Set Browser in the Launcher window (select Changes → Change Sets from the System menu), and in the new Browser, select Add... from the ChangeSet or the <Operate> menu. Enter a name for the new change set in the prompter dialog, and click OK.
To make this the current change set, select it so it is highlighted. All subsequent changes will be recorded to this change set.

topic.title: Save the contents of a single change set

body.p: change setsave contentsUse File out as... in the left view’s <Operate> menu. To file out all projects into a directory, use File out all....
Change sets only keep track of the parts of the system that have been modified. Unlike Change Lists, change sets do not keep track of the evolution of changes.
change setemptyTo empty the active change set, in readiness for a new batch of work, select Empty... in the <Operate> menu.

change listfind conflicts code conflictsTo identify conflicting methods in a source file (or group of source files) displayed in the Change List, select Read different source from file/directory... on the File menu. This command will build a list of changes using only those definitions in the source file which differ from the system. A full source text comparison is performed, so any changes to formatting or comments will be flagged, and the corresponding methods or classes will be added to the list of changes.

If you want to perform this operation using code analysis instead of raw source comparison, select Read different code from file/directory... on the File menu. Changes to formatting or comments will be ignored, and only methods or classes with code changes will be added to the list of changes. Note that although names of temporary variables are often considered part of the source, they are treated as code changes by this analysis.
These commands are equivalent to file in/out → read file/directory..., followed by Same....

code conflictsTo locate places where the same method or class is affected in the Change List, use the conflicts → check conflicts, save as... command on the <Operate> menu in the upper-left view. Every duplicate entry in the change list will be checked, and all versions of the conflicting code are then saved in the designated file. This command can be used to identify conflicts when you are integrating code from multiple files.
To perform a similar conflict-check between the list of changes and the corresponding definitions in the current image, use the conflicts → check with system, save as... command.
